user.biography: The most powerful stories from human history.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered in Finland. May be an image of text that says 'Archaeologists In Finland Just Unearthed A Life-Sized 4,400-Ye-Old Wooden Snake They Believe Was Used By Shamans'.

node.text:
"I have seen many extraordinary things in my work as a wetland archaeologist, but the discovery of this figurine made me utterly speechless and gave me the shivers."⁠
⁠
Archaeologists in Finland have unearthed a roughly two-foot wooden staff delicately carved into the shape of a snake with its mouth open. Aside from being incredibly lifelike, experts believe the staff was used by Stone-Age shamans as a means of communicating with the dead — or turning themselves into snakes. Go inside this significant find by clicking the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
⁠
#archaeology #worldhistory #europeanhsitory #finland #ancienthistory #shaman #stoneage

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered on July 29, 2021. May be a black-and-white image of 3 people and people standing.

node.text:
"He is setting a fine example for the youth of this country."⁠
⁠
On October 28, 1956, Elvis Presley got the polio vaccine on live TV — and inspired countless fans to follow his lead. At the time, many Americans were hesitant to take the shot due to an early bad batch that had killed four people and left 51 people paralyzed. But when viewers saw the King of Rock 'n' Roll receive his vaccine, they felt far more confident about its safety. This was especially true for teenagers. After Presley's TV appearance,, vaccination rates among teens rose from 0.6 to 80 percent in just six months.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to learn more about how the King of Rock and Roll helped eradicate polio.⁠
⁠
⁠
#elvis #elvispresley #polio #vaccines #1956 #1950s #ushistory

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered on July 29, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and indoor.

node.text:
"I sincerely hope that I shall always be a credit to my race and the motion picture industry."⁠
⁠
Even though Hattie McDaniel became the first black person to win an Academy Award in America, she was often seen by activists as a disservice to their cause by portraying stereotypes of black people on screen. McDaniel had won the award for her role as the wise slave named "Mammy" in "Gone With The Wind" and her appearances all over the country in her Mammy get-up outraged people of color.⁠
⁠
Learn about her controversial legacy by visiting the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
⁠
#hattiemcdaniel #historyoffilm #gonewiththewind #movies #blackhistory

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered on July 28, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Inside The Raucous Life And Gory Death OfBlackbeard, History's Most Infamous Pirate'.

node.text:
The most fearsome pirate in history, Blackbeard dressed all in black with six pistols strapped to his chest and slow-burning fuses woven into his long dark beard, giving the impression that he was more demon than man as he boarded the ships of his prey. Fueled by his carefully cultivated reputation for terror, he swept through the early 18th-century Caribbean and easily plundered some $15 million.⁠
⁠
And he upheld his chilling reputation however he needed to, including shooting his own first mate in front of his men, just because "if he didn't shoot one or two [crewmen] now and then, they'd forget who he was." Click the link in our profile to discover the full story of Blackbeard.⁠
⁠
⁠
#pirates #edwardteach #history #blackbeard

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered on July 28, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and military uniform.

node.text:
When Soviet cosmonaut Vladimir Komarov was tapped to pilot the Soyuz I mission in 1967, he knew he might not come back alive.⁠
⁠
Not only was space travel itself new, but Komarov's spacecraft was quite rushed — and may have even experienced issues during the testing period. Tragically, Komarov's mission failed and he became the first human to die in spaceflight. And when the Soviets recovered his corpse, all that was left of him was a charred "lump."⁠
⁠
Learn the devastating story of the man who fell from space by clicking the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
#vladimirkomarov #soviet #soyuzmission #space

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered on July 28, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and standing.

node.text:
Later immortalized in song by Bob Marley, the "Buffalo Soldiers" were the first all-Black units to serve in the U.S. Army during peacetime. Just after the Civil War, these pioneering regiments were forced by racist superiors to patrol the harsh terrain of the Wild West.⁠
⁠
And not only did they do it with legendary bravery, they did it in style. Their bold look was the envy of the West as "White explorers on the Lewis and Clark trail coveted the robes." Learn the full story of the Buffalo soldiers by visiting the link in our profile.⁠
⁠
⁠
#buffalosoldier #ushistory #blackhistory #historyofusmilitary

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered on July 27, 2021. May be an illustration of 4 people.

node.text:
On December 23, 1890, an English woman named Mary Pearcey was hanged for the brutal murder of her lover's wife and child. According to authorities, Pearcey had thrown the baby into the street and then slit the woman's throat so deeply that she was nearly decapitated. Then at her trial, Pearcey said, "My sentence is a just one, but a good deal of the evidence against me was false."⁠
⁠
The meaning behind that eerie message remains unknown, but some claim that Pearcey was confessing to being the notorious "Jack the Ripper," who had butchered five women in London's Whitechapel District just two years before she was executed. In addition to her bizarre "confession," Pearcey's modus operandi was shockingly similar to the Ripper's. And shortly before her execution, she had placed a mysterious ad in a Spanish newspaper that read "M.E.C.P. Last wish of M.E.W. Have not betrayed." Some believe that "M.E.W." refers to her maiden name, Mary Eleanor Wheeler, and that "M.E.C.P." refers to four Ripper victims: Mary Jane Kelly, Elizabeth Stride, Catherine Eddowes, and Polly Nichols.⁠
⁠
Take a closer look at the chilling theory that Jack the Ripper was actually a woman by visiting the link in our profile.⁠
⁠
⁠
#marypearcey #jacktheripper #whowasjacktheripper #historyuncovered #englishhistory #victorianengland

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered in New York, New York. May be an image of one or more people and people standing.

node.text:
After being rejected by their male literary peers, women writers of New York City joined forces to create their own club in 1868 called Sorosis — where men weren't allowed. Sorosis became such a phenomenon that even men applied to join its ranks. They were rejected with the following statement:⁠
⁠
"We willingly admit, of course, that the accident of your sex is on your part a misfortune and not a fault; nor do we wish to arrogate anything to ourselves, because we had the good fortune to be born women... Sorosis is too young for the society of gentlemen and must be allowed time to grow... But for years to come its reply to all male suitors must be, 'Principles, not men.'"⁠
⁠
To learn more about this exclusive women's club, click the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
⁠
⁠
#janecroly #nyc #mensclub #womensclub #sorosis #womenssociety

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered on July 27, 2021. May be a drawing of 1 person.

node.text:
Although matchstick making sounds like a simple job, the consequences of working around the materials that were needed to make them were truly devastating.⁠
⁠
Matchsticks were made in factories by women and children who labored for 12 to 16 hours a day, and the process involved dipping the wood matchsticks into a phosphorous solution. The problem with the job was that too much exposure to phosphorus carried a risk specific to matchstick makers: phossy jaw.⁠
⁠
Essentially, phossy jaw was a physical ailment that causes the jaw bone to rot. The disease was known to spread to the brain and cause a very painful death unless the jaw was removed. Even with jaw removal, these factory workers still weren’t guaranteed to survive.⁠
⁠
Follow the link in our profile to read more about some of history's worst jobs.⁠
⁠
⁠
#phosphorus #factories #matchmaking #jobs #history #sad⁠ #historyuncovered

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered in Crete. May be an image of text that says 'The 4,000 Old Code On The Ancient Greek Phaistos Disc Has Just Been Cracked'.

node.text:
In 1908, Italian archaeologist Luigi Pernier was exploring the 4,000-year-old Minoan palace of Phaistos on the island of Crete. After venturing into its subterranean temple, he sifted through dust, ashes, and burned human bones before happening upon a clay disk covered in strange hieroglyphs.⁠
⁠
Just 15 centimeters in diameter, the Phaistos Disc contained a mysterious code that features 240 characters made up of 45 different symbols — none of which belong to any known alphabet. Not only was the language unknown, but experts have never found another artifact that features these same bizarre symbols.⁠
⁠
For more than a century since, the case of the Phaistos Disc has gone unsolved — until now. After devoting 30 years of his life to studying the disc, one intrepid linguist has finally solved this Bronze Age puzzle — read more at the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
⁠
#ancienthistory #ancientmystery #phaistosdisc #whoa #fascinating #historynews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered in Inyo County, California. May be an image of tree and nature.

node.text:
In the summer of 1957, dendrochronologist Edmund Schulman stumbled upon a small grove of ancient trees in the Inyo Valley in eastern California. All of them were upwards of 4,000 years old, but one in particular stood out: a tree that clocked in at 4,789 years old, making it the oldest tree on Earth.⁠
⁠
Schulman dubbed it the Methuselah tree in honor of the grandfather of the Ark-building Noah, who was said to have lived to be 969 years old. Now the tree had a name, but its location has remained a secret for decades in the interest of protecting this ancient conifer and those surrounding it. To learn more about the oldest tree known to man, visit the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
⁠
#edmundschulman #methuselah #methuselahtree #inyovalley #california #earthhistory #naturalhistory #trees

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered in Australia.

node.text:
"All my son wanted to do was to see the world. He had itchy feet. His determination to see how the rest of the world lives has cost him his life."⁠
⁠
Just months before 14-year-old Keith Sapsford fell to his death from a plane in 1970, his father had warned him against becoming a stowaway. Charles Sapsford knew his son was constantly looking for adventure and even warned him about a stowaway who had died on a plane.⁠
⁠
But tragically, his son couldn't contain his urge to fly away and soon met the same fate — and a photographer accidentally captured his fatal fall. Read the rest of the tragic story by visiting the link in our profile.⁠
⁠
⁠
#keithsapsford #historyofaustralia #worldhistory #1970 #airplanes #stowaway
